results.content:
I am sure that Neil meant to do a good job, but this course (for me) is just a whole lot of copy and pasting, very little explanation on what is happening and why it is happening that way. If you are an experienced programmer who is already familiar with these concepts and are just curious how to accomplish them with angular, this would be a great course. 

If you however are like me, and do not have a solid background in web applications, do not start here, or at the very least be aware that this course will show you how to make a dating app, but not give you the knowledge to create your own unique web app with your own unique functionality. I am roughly 7 hours in, and I would say 90-95% of my time has been spent copying and pasting code, so clueless as to what I am doing that I hardly even know when I am allowed to tweak things.

Perhaps the problem is me, and I truly feel the instructor tried very hard. He is funny at times, the course has good video and audio quality. But I feel like this is a course on how to make a dating app, as opposed to how to make a web application.

I truly feel like I haven't learned anything.

Edit: An important part of this review I forgot to include. The course is described as being aimed at people with a 1 out of 10 understanding of programming. On that scale zero reflects zero knowledge of programming. This was what made me take the course, however after 7 or so hours of following along with this course, it is definitely not aimed at people with a 1 out of 10 skill level, or even a 1- 4 skill level. Also apparently 7 hours in long enough to no longer qualify for a refund, so that's great haha....

results.content:
Instructor is in desperate need of a stricter set of outlines and a way to separate scope of each lesson. Gets lost in the weeds and is often disparate in skill levels (stopping mid declaration to go into eg inheritance or garbage collection in the most surface-level way possible is not helpful for anyone, least of all those who are very new to coding). These CS-101 concept lessons should be separate concept introductions and not weird diversions, the focus in the main lesson should be progressing with a workable prototype. That way when these concepts are encountered later they can be pointed out and not mulled over in yet another useless 5 minute long diversion.

This is a course for nobody: an introduction that will either be too advanced or too simple for anybody who is looking. Intermediate or better programmers (in regards to programming concepts specifically) will learn what is on the tin but will feel like much of the runtime is wasted. Intro programmers will be able to follow the tutorial but will struggle to apply the lessons later on. I'd recommend as an introduction to angular and to skim the rest. Has no useful quiz sections and for some reason the instructor insists on coding C# on a mac knowing full well that most of the world will not be doing so. It's a nice proof-of-concept but absolutely baffling in an introductory course and will only help it age faster.

On the plus side updating the course for newer versions of dotnet core is pretty awesome. The included resources are nice (would have been nicer to have the students create some of that content, especially nice to show how certificates can be created as that's a big issue -- might come up later I'm not through the whole thing yet). There's better out there but this has potential to be a 4 star at least with a lot of content tightening. Maybe next time.

results.content:
Great course that delivers exactly what it's title claims. There is an impressive breadth of content covered over 20 hours. Good choices were made throughout the course in choosing tooling and libraries that are currently up to date (1/18) and field proven. 

Expectations for this course would be best met if either you already have a good background in C#, Typescript, ASP.NET Core and Angular and need to fill in your knowledge gaps, or if you understand that you will need to follow up this course with more detailed courses on the major topics covered.

My only complaint would be that the section on Publishing is used to both refactor some warnings in the API and changes relative to Angular 5 as well as the actual publishing lectures. The cleanup and migration lectures should really live in their own section.

results.content:
The required level for this course is far more than the beginner. Even in I have a Software Engineering degree and have some experience in various languages, this course is crushing my head right from the beginning. Incapsulation, Interfaces, Constructors, Lambda operations, Models, MVC and so on. You should be pretty fluent in OOP to have a clue what is going on here since teacher is not wasting his time on such simple concepts.
It's not the right place to start your .NET journey, this course is for Intermediate listeners.

results.content_html: My department has adopted Angular/Core 2 for our development going forward, so we have been training with multiple tutorials on both topics. In my opinion, this course has been the best overall as far as covering both topics - especially in teaching how both technologies integrate. I substituted SQL Server for the SQL Lite database and it was not a problem. I'm going to recommend Neil's course to the other developers in my area for training.

results.content:
Whilst this is labelled as a beginner level course, I would not advise this to someone who has zero coding knowledge. I actually grade this as an intermediate difficulty. This is why I really like the course; having done some .NET server side development before, I found this course further developed my existing coding knowledge in a practical way, with a useful real world example. I think on uDemy there are far too many courses targeting complete beginners, it's easy then to get swept up with 10s of courses on the same topic in the uDemy sales that aren't bettering knowledge. This is definitely a course to follow along with and complete start to finish.

It is set out in a modular way, building or expanding a new piece of functionality that can be referred back to in the future and utilised in other applications that might be built. This modularity also made for good opportunities to pause the course, and do some research of my own to further understand a particular aspect of .NET or Angular.

Another great thing I liked is the helpfulness of the tutor in Q&A and he completely rewrote the course from Angular 4 to 6, thus I am hopeful that if Angular 7 comes out next month, he will do the same again.

I'm definitely going to be watching for anything Neil does in the future.

results.content:
I came into this course not knowing anything about C# and to be honest the way he built the API confused me a lot but that's because he is doing it in a very professional manner with lots of reusable code and good design patterns.

If you have no knowledge of C# or .NET - SUPPLEMENTAL LEARNING IS NECESSARY!

That said, he teaches you so many underrated web development concepts that no other course teaches you. It's the little things such as pop up notifications asking if you're sure you want to leave the page when you have made changes to something.

Things like that will teach you how to professionally develop a modern website.

Don't expect great styling from this course but in terms of funcitonality and backend learning, this is the best course I've ever done.

results.content:
High quality course. Best I've seen so far on Udemy! Impressive. You accomplish a lot in a relatively short period of time, and the project can be used as a "template/reference" to help you build your own apps. 

Some features are very fun to build, like the authentication, photo uploading, and messaging components. 
The instructor moves at a fast pace, so you'll want to take advantage of all of the shortcut key and autocomplete features in VS Code to keep up. I had to pause the video frequently to keep up and research issues I had due to typos (which was good in a way, since I learned how things work better by debugging) - so be prepared to spend a good amount of time on this one - especially if you aren't able to keep up.

Hands-down, this is the best online course I've taken to learn a web technology. It's a long course and covers a lot of ground, but Neil teaches in a way that makes the learning fun and interesting. I feel that I now have a good understanding of Angular 6 and know enough to start using this framework in future projects.

Neil takes you through developing a web application that enables you to explore the most important ASP.NET Core Web API and Angular features and other pieces such Typescript, Entity Framework, Bootstrap and useful Angular libraries.

results.content: The course is not about syntactic rules or complex nuances of C# and TypeScript, but it is all about the best practices and effective patterns that could be extremely useful in your ASP.NET/Angular applications. In my opinion, the example of the application fit perfectly for the goal of the course: it is not too simple to be boring and is not too complex to fail. Frankly speaking, I got in a trap when I started migrations from ASP.NET 2.0 to 2.1, Angular 4.0 to 6/7 and Twitter Bootstrap 3 to 4. It was too close to frustration, but, you know, the adventure was awesome! Yes, the course is one of the most useful and interesting on Udemy!

results.content:
Excellent course, I would have give it 6 stars if I could.  The best I have done so far on Udemy.

No issues with environment or versioning like some other courses.  As of the date of this review I completed the course with no issues.

A tip:
There are not many exercises in this course, although Neil has added a couple of challenges.
I recommend in the second half of the course to pause and attempt to code some of the sections yourself.  Neil always explains beforehand what he's about to do, so you can just pause and give it a go.  More time consuming but definitely improves learning.

results.content:
The course moves insanely fast at times -- to the point where it feels less like "a class where you learn things," and more like "a tutorial where you just follow these exact steps." But then again, I'm not sure how you could structure such a course to be the former. 

I knew how to setup an MVC app with Entity Framework and ASPNET Core in Visual Studio, so I haven't been terribly lost (it's been months since I've used that info, so I'm here for a refresher for a new job). In fact, a lot of the early videos give a "behind the scenes" look at what Entity abstracted away from me. But at the same time, I feel that you need to know how most of these systems and structures work before parts of this course will make sense, and perhaps isn't the best for near-beginners as he mentions in the intro. 

I don't regret my time spent with this course at all. Just wanted to say, it does move fast, and things can get confusing at times. Perhaps it comes with the territory.
results.content_html:

I knew how to setup an MVC app with Entity Framework and ASPNET Core in Visual Studio, so I haven't been terribly lost (it's been months since I've used that info, so I'm here for a refresher for a new job). In fact, a lot of the early videos give a "behind the scenes" look at what Entity abstracted away from me. But at the same time, I feel that you need to know how most of these systems and structures work before parts of this course will make sense, and perhaps isn't the best for near-beginners as he mentions in the intro.

I don't regret my time spent with this course at all. Just wanted to say, it does move fast, and things can get confusing at times. Perhaps it comes with the territory.

results.content: This course is excellent for anyone wanting get into web development using .NET Core. You'll be coding alongside Neil throughout the course, and he provides explanations to core functionally and concepts in each section. He's also active in the Q&A of the course, so if you happen to get stuck or encounter an error, he's likely to respond very quickly. I'd recommend this course to anyone with an interest in programming and creating web applications.

I highly recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn Asp.net core with Angular.

results.content:
So far, I believe there are some things that are beyond the level of "Hello World" in both .NET Core and Angular, but having used .Net and Javascript heavily before I'm keeping up fine.  You cover a lot of ground quickly and outside reading ("Googling") will likely be required to take in everything.  Neil does a great job at keeping the information moving at pace and we are looking forward to starting our first production app in .Net Core and Angular next week.

I highly recommend this course.

results.content:
The content of this course was very useful. This was NOT Hello World or let's use students, instructors and grades. The concepts were real

Throughout the course you'll learn how to build your own ideas/tools/concepts as well as understanding how to use 3rd party tools. 

I really liked that every time we brought in an external tool that we visited the website, learned how to explore the capabilities of the tool and then implemented the same. This is different that most lessons where an instructor just says use this library and type these things because I said so. Everything was quite transparent.

We were informed of what we'd build; we built it, then we reviewed what we built.

I'm a fan of the content and the instructor.

results.content: As appropriately titled, this course takes you from setting up the development environment, learning Angular 6, ASP.NET Core with EF Core all the way to deploying the application not just on web servers but all the way to Azure. I liked the fact that there wasn't any time spent on comparing Angular 6 with previous versions and explaining the upgrade path. Same with no playing around with CSS beyond what makes prudent sense. I was working on my own app in parallel with Neil and his explanation was enough to help me complete it. Pretty much every query was answered in the course soon after the query came up in my mind. I also liked the best practices introduced in the course like SCM, global errors handling, global filters, seeding data, etc. In my opinion this course has been an excellent experience, with nothing really to complain.

der Lösungen für viele alltägliche Problemstellungen vorstellt und erläutert. Das Vorgehen entspricht dem eines Entwicklers in der Praxis, weil es an der Problemstellung anstatt an der Fachsystematik orientiert ist. Dadurch gewinnt der Kurs eine  hohe Praxisrelevanz.

Well done, Neil!

results.content:
The course was very well organized and Neil was thorough in explaining why certain things were done in a way. The course is really good for beginners as it lays foundation for exploration and the sample application built as the course progresses is also really neat. Please take time to go through the sample as you progress as it helps cement the understanding of the concepts demonstrated in each module. The course is very well paced, engaging and kept up to date. Great Work from Neil. 

Only thing I missed in the course was having a reference document like a PDF or Presentation, something to cover the whole module once they were completed or for later reference. This would be really helpful to revise the core concepts. Though without this reference as well the course is a 5 star.

This should be a prime example on how to build a course on any tech stack.

results.content: Excellent course!  The choice of app and features built covers many ASPNET Core, Angular plus third party topics.  The course is up to date and Neil does a great job of responding to questions.  This is definitely not a beginners course (the focus is on building an app rather than how to code and best coding practices etc.) but if you have software dev experience and are new to ASPNET Core/Angular, you should be good.  An improvement would be to involve more challenges.  Overall I would highly recommend this course; stick with it, sometimes go off-piste (try building the feature before Neil shows you how), learn and enjoy!

results.content: So far in the course, you use the command palette (which being new to this IDE I didn't even know how to bring it up), if you're going to use a short cut key for the first time it would be nice to hear about it since we cant see what shortcut you used to launch anything from a keyboard.  You also refer to the restore option once a nuget package is installed.  What does the restore do and why is it performed, is it critical can it just be done later, should you mention if you miss running the restore that the notifications section in the IDE can allow you to hit restore.  Again first time useage, no idea what these things are or where they are located.  Originally I was trying to use visual studio 2017 because its what we have in the office for software development, but the nuget command console alone is impossible to understand and so I have given up.  I get the appeal of the code IDE but if software professionals are going to be taking this course there's a lot of value in helping us to understand an IDE will will be expected to use.  I can't really say thanks for visual studio and its cost but I'm just going to go it alone with he free IDE.  As a software engineer of 25+ years but coming at this from a business basic background, I can follow along with your coding but the speed through the tool set loses me sometimes.

results.content: Una maravilla. No disfrutaba tanto recibiendo un curso de informática desde la asignatura de compiladores de 4º de Ingeniería Informática, allá por el año 97. He seguido otros cursos/tutoriales de Angular y Bootstrap pero me han parecido muy pesados porque se centran en ir viendo todos los componentes y se hacen muy repetitivos, pues visto un componente, vistos todos. Aquí se va a lo esencial que es demostrar el funcionamiento de todas las capas de una aplicación SPA en el modelo de objetos cliente/servidor, usando algunos de los componentes representativos y dándote las pautas para que tú sepas donde buscar y como integrar otros componentes que necesites. El ritmo y la claridad del profesor son esenciales  y Neil es muy bueno en eso. Con ese contenido y por ese precio es una joya.

results.content:
This is an excellent, in-depth course about ASP.Net Core and Angular, and I learnt a lot about building a great application from scratch. Neil was an engaging and knowledgeable instructor, and very responsive in the Q&A section. Concepts explored in the course would surely come in handy in real world applications.

The only minor issue I had was, I feel that the instructor could have given more in-depth explanations on concepts used. I was a beginner in Angular and TypeScript before this course, so most of the syntax and semantics was lost on me (at least at the beginning) until I made an effort to google material and read up on them myself. But I also want to put a positive spin to this, by saying that this is not a spoon-fed course, which a lot of other Udemy courses tend to be. It challenges and makes us take an effort, which is best in the long run.

results.content:
As a developer often up-skilling, I am particular about courses. Neil Cummings and course content is everything one could want in a course. Content is structured, and presented clearly.

What I particularly enjoyed getting more than just the basics of ASP.NET Core and Angular. Neil generously showed how one can practically apply newly learnt frameworks into a realistic web application.  Better than "Hello World" examples.

This course serves well to help prepare established developers wanting to pivot from traditional development into newer full stack development.

As a developer often up-skilling, I am particular about courses. Neil Cummings and course content is everything one could want in a course. Content is structured, and presented clearly.

What I particularly enjoyed getting more than just the basics of ASP.NET Core and Angular. Neil generously showed how one can practically apply newly learnt frameworks into a realistic web application. Better than "Hello World" examples.

This course serves well to help prepare established developers wanting to pivot from traditional development into newer full stack development.

results.content:
I really enjoyed this course and learned a substantial amount about developing a full stack web application that I have had a hard time finding in other courses.  Currently, I am shifting from being a desktop developer of 16+ years to becoming a web developer.  I've done some web development over the years, but I want to develop using a REST framework and being a .Net developer, I admire Microsoft's new ASP.Net Core framework.  As well, I have become quite fond of Angular.  However, merging the two technologies together has been a very tough topic.  I have yet to see anywhere, where someone will go into such depth in how to develop such a large project with both an ASP.Net backend and an Angular front-end.   

Neil's teaching style is very understandable and easy to follow along. As well, he gives good example, keeps a decent pace, without speeding along too fast or lingering too long.  He does a good job explaining every situation you may encounter and discussing in great detail every step he takes and makes it very easy to program along with him.     As well, when I was having problems,  he was very quick to respond and does his best to help you with any issue you incur and did on more than one occasion point out some errors I made that I overlooked.

I have to say Neil Cummings has went above and beyond and this is probably the best ASP.Net/Angular course you will find anywhere on the internet.  I have looked around thoroughly.  Microsoft should seriously consider promoting this course to any newbie or even skilled developer looking for a great step-by-step guide on how to develop your ASP.Net API against an Angular front-end.  The Microsoft tutorials have always been a bit lacking when it comes to ASP.Net CORE. 

Neil's course with the new Identity module gives it a pretty comprehensive overview of ASP.Net.  The Angular front-end is quite detailed.  However, this is not a pure Angular course, so if you want a very comprehensive and more in-depth instruction on Angular, itself, then I would consider taking this course as a starter and than looking at Maximillian Schwarzmueller's course on Angular, which is the most comprehensive Angular course I have seen anywhere.  I am taking both Neil and Max's courses together and have found the two have given me an education on developing full stack web apps with Angular and ASP.Net that I probably could have not acquired anywhere else.

I wanted to thank you Neil for your efforts in producing this course and appreciate how you keep it updated and responsive you are.  I will be checking back with this course time to time both for updates and as a reference with my ASP.Net/Angular development.     I just received my first Udemy certificate today from completing this course :D  

P.S.
I also want to say how much I admire the Photo Management challenge. That is probably the best exercise I have had in any online course and it really refined and tested my skills more than I could imagine.

results.content:
As opposed to the 'rock and roll kids' who slope around fast and loose with little apparent experience introducing code that ends up not working and from whom no answers will be found querying them, here comes a voice of reason, someone past their puberty who speaks confidently yet not cockily, from experience and with the poise you expect from an expert.

The content has been digested and reflected upon extensively as you'll see. The structure is well laid out, the code works, and the rhythm is perfect.

It is truly a pleasure to learn with this instructor. I have purchased a dozen courses so far and reviewed as a reviewer twice as much, and this instructor tops them all.

Chapeau from Vancouver!

results.content:
I read the other reviews saying that the course was not very well explained but after seeing the video specify "you need to be a 'level 1' on a scale of 10" I thought I would try.  I have dabbled with C# (Written a few desktop applications), HTML, PHP, Java and I use SQL for my day job, I thought this would be perfect for me but on that rating scale I would say you need to be a 4 - at least.

Very little of what you are doing is explained.  What IS a derived class?  why did I create a controller and what does it do?  And the whole thing is paced so quickly I am finding myself just trying to type fast enough to keep up and having to pause to repeat parts where the narrative didn't mention a click or something typed.

I got to the end of Section 2, 2 hours and I have no idea what I had actually achieved except for making a single table database - let alone try to build my own site using what I learned here.  I wouldn't have a clue how to repeat what I had done let alone apply it to my own projects.  It is one of those courses where you just follow what the tutor does, create the project, but still have no idea how to build a website yourself.

Maybe I'm just dumb but if you are a beginner or have very little experience with C# or ASP, I would avoid.  I am going to try to refund and get a course more suited to me.
results.content_html:

I have dabbled with C# (Written a few desktop applications), HTML, PHP, Java and I use SQL for my day job, I thought this would be perfect for me but on that rating scale I would say you need to be a 4 - at least.

Very little of what you are doing is explained. What IS a derived class? why did I create a controller and what does it do? And the whole thing is paced so quickly I am finding myself just trying to type fast enough to keep up and having to pause to repeat parts where the narrative didn't mention a click or something typed.

I got to the end of Section 2, 2 hours and I have no idea what I had actually achieved except for making a single table database - let alone try to build my own site using what I learned here. I wouldn't have a clue how to repeat what I had done let alone apply it to my own projects. It is one of those courses where you just follow what the tutor does, create the project, but still have no idea how to build a website yourself.

Maybe I'm just dumb but if you are a beginner or have very little experience with C# or ASP, I would avoid. I am going to try to refund and get a course more suited to me.

results.content:
Excellent course. My previous world was several years of C#, Asp.Net MVC (WebApi and Front end) with solid Javascript (JQuery, several other Javascript libs, Typescript etc) and many different databases. I had not worked previously with .net core and Angular. This is a great course to get into the newer way of doing things if you were still coding using approaches that may have been cutting-edge 7 or 8 years ago. But times move on. 

If you have never worked with C#, and in particular lambda expressions, you might struggle with some things here. So go learn that stuff first before doing this course.

results.content:
Clear instructions so far with great diction. The director gives a clear vision and blueprint from start to finish. His way of explaining design decisions is great, of handling errors calms me noticeably. The process is practical every step of the way, staying challenging and informative despite some clear instructions. Halfway through, I feel very confident in .NET, Angular, Postman, DB Browser, and the numerous third-party packages he's made good use of.

The instructor is very supportive, answering many questions personally and as helpfully as he possibly can, for which I am very thankful. He has also done an admiral job keeping the course updated with changes in the software, and I hope he continues to. While I'd suggest people do at least a beginner's course in C# before this, I can only give this course a hard recommend. Five stars.

results.content: I have seen a few Angular and .Net courses in different places such as Youtube, PluralSight and here in Udemy... this course is by far the BEST one I have seen. The instructor shows a complete and well-planned project, which covers a fair range of tools and real-world scenarios. I haven’t completed the full course yet, but I am so happy to what I got that I am rating it now. My only (and small) criticism is that I think we should have a small module for refactoring and clean the code, I just think that sometimes we mixed logic in places where it should not be (controllers). But I am happy enough and, definitely, will buy his course again.

results.content: This is easily the best course I've taken on Udemy, and gets 6 out of 5 stars from me.  Part of the reason is that the author has updated the entire course to use the latest available frameworks, so everything just works without having to spend time looking for workarounds online.  Also, he goes over EVERYTHING including detailed instructions on setting up your VS Code, which is no small task as there are dozens of components that come into play and need to work together in this full stack course.  He's knowledgable about the subject and a native Englishs speaker, which is a big plus as well (though I'd prefer American accent over his British, but it's just me nitpicking at this point).  I was actually kind of bummed he only has two courses available, as I would gladly purchase more.

results.content: Course was going great until the publishing section.  I learned a lot from this course and got the website up and running on my local environment. When it came time to publish the site to Heroku, the course fell flat. Based on the comments less than half the students were able to get the site to work on Heroku with a lot of the students questions left unanswered. It was also apparent that the instructor skipped a few steps in the publishing process which some students were able to figure out and some weren't (like me). That shouldn't really happen though as everything the teacher does should be documented. I would have rated this course a 5 star if it weren't for all the mishaps in the last section. Still I like the instructors teaching style so I would still say it was a positive experience overall. At this point I'm halfway through the instructors next course (Reactivities) which is going well so far.

The only downside is sometimes it can feel a little rushed but that is being picky.

Having just finished the course, I can say it is amazing. 
     It is very well-thought, giving very detailed but not too deep explanations of how Angular and .Net Core work. 
You can never cover full stack technologies in one course - but Neil did a "healthy introduction" to both of them! 
   One of the biggest points in the course are "challenges" where instructor asks students to solve the problems themselves. And I wish there could be more. So much new information is hard to digest without sufficient practice.

Overall - highly recommend

results.content:
Very concise, no fluff - the topic is also great, .NET Core + Angular 5 is a really great and modern cross platform combination. Delivery is also very clear and easy to understand.

The instructor is using Windows 10 as opposed to macOS, which is relevant to more developers - 2018 Stack Overflow Developer Survey shows 49.9% of devs are using Windows... only 26.7% are macOS (and all 26.7% of those macOS devs seem to be Udemy instructors :-) ). This course is still great for macOS and Linux based devs too.

Also, Visual Studio Code is the #1 code editor at the moment, and this is the editor that is being used for the lessons, which is great because its got amazing TypeScript AND .net Core support!

Neil also added some extra lessons for updating the project to Angular 6 - this also was very good!

results.content:
I've really enjoyed the course. I like the approach that we are building a full working application from zero to deploy. Instructor is really active and does respond to questions usually within 24h, which is really appreciated.

I have a deep Node.js and Go knowledge, so seeing how it is done in ASP.NET Core with C# was very refreshing.
Though, some design decissions might have been different in my opinion (like use websockets for messaging or different handling of secrets such as api keys and tokens)

Overall however this is one of the best courses on .ASP.NET Core with Angular I've seen.

results.content:
This course suffers from the same issue as many (if not MOST) video courses suffer from, and that's the "ease" of video. Because it's easy to talk and record a screen, video tends to be much looser and unfocused than a written tutorial, which requires more effort to create and therefore more thought. 

For example, there have been several times where the instructor has stumbled over something or misspoke -- very normal things, but in a professional course I would expect the instructor to use a second take. Instead, it's just left as kind of confusing for someone new to the material (remember! People new to the material have no idea what's happening for the first little while, and it's SUPER IMPORTANT to be SUPER CLEAR.)

Also, as a suggestion, repeat shortcuts (mac and windows, plus maybe linux) as they're used. One quick description five videos ago is not enough to remember.

results.content:
Some folks binge watch Netflix; I have been binge coding along with Neil in this course. The teaching style is very engaging and, of course, I like the subject!  I was working all day today in the course when I noticed an announcement email regarding the course getting an update tomorrow.  I am impressed that Neil chose the method best for his students and harder on himself.  

I have read and worked through a number of books on the Angular 2+ tools. This has to be the best and most practical course on the subject that I have seen to date! You will learn more than Angular and Microsoft's Web API using the .Net Core, you will also learn how to use the VS Code editor. Additionally you will learn how to find and integrate third party libraries, use the EntityFramework, some CSS 3 tricks to add pizzaz, and other goodies along the journey.

Thank you, Neil!

Wayne

I wanted to learn more about the backend web api implementation and the usage of JWT, Claims, Paging, Sorting, Filtering, EF, DTOs and Repository Pattern.  I wanted a course that covered the whole gamut and this course did a pretty good job at doing so.

It is also great that the course has been update for Angular v8 and .Net Core 2.2.

results.content:
The course is quite interesting and covers a lot of different topics (SignalR, Identity, ngx-bootstrap, .NET 5.0), which made me buy it, however there are some areas for improvement:
1. I had to fix bugs dozens of times - the author sometimes forgets to tell about the changes made to the code between the videos.
2. There is too little theory part - it would be nice to know how the things work under the hood, while this course was more like dictation or speedrun.
3. The author does not show the best code - for instance, the author places business logic into controllers instead of services. Controllers should not know anything about Unit of Work and Repositories. The author uses mapper in repositories, which is not good either etc. I would not mind if the autor did not introduce these patterns in the course, but, in my opinion, it introduces the wrong way of using them in entetrprise applications.

In general, this course is OK for beginners, who want to have some hands-on experience in Angular and .NET, but you will have to remember that business applications are developed in a different way.

results.content:
This is a fantastic course. First it uses technologies I am already using at work and helped augment what I already knew. I know AngularJS and this course taught me how to apply Angular using an architecture similar to what I am used to in an ASP.NET web site.

The instructor is very knowledgeable and explained things very clearly. I obtained a good foot in the door for using Angular and believe I can create my own site using the skills I learned in this course.

I also liked how the course builds a web site and that I can see what I accomplished at the end. 

One recommendation is the instructor should have  setup the course in GitHub from the start. The course first creates the skeleton of the application. Any mistake and I found I had to start over. If the instructor has the student setup Github say after the first lecture in setting up the application skeleton it would be very helpful. Before being setup in GitHub I was zipping up each lecture so I had something to fall back to. I had to do the skeleton section twice as Github wasn't setup.

Also I would recommend saving to GitHub at the end of each lecture and not the end of each section. I found a few times I needed to revert back and this was very helpful.

Finally since you have to type the code out yourself (the instructor does have the entire course in GitHub, but note branch by section or lecture) mistakes can happen. I found I learned a lot when having to correct these mistakes. They didn't happen to often however.

As the instructor stresses from the beginning you need to have prior knowledge in Software Development and with C# and ASP.NET. This is not a beginner programming course.

I have watched dozens and dozens of courses on many websites. That teacher is the best so far. And just to show how much he cares, he has updated that course from Aspnet core 2.2 to 3.0.

he could easily have said that the course is for aspnet core 2.2. 

But he took his time to record some extra slides and update us about the change so we could follow along with a newer version.

Never seen a teacher doing it before. 

well done Neil!!

results.content_html:
Course Content:
Greatest way to learn something is by working on a real-life example. That's what we get to do in this course and is my favorite part about it. If you do not know anything about Angular or .NET Core and looking to learn, this course is for you. Go for it.

Instructor:
Great instructor giving clear and to-the-point explanations and prompt and in-depth replies to queries.

results.content:
I come from a PHP background, wanting to venture into a strongly typed programming language. I must say I've watched and followed many different tutorials, but the way Neil delivers his knowledge is just superb!

I somewhat drifted away from angular (after the rewrite) in favour of Vue.js but this tutorial not only taught me a ton on .NET Core it has also rekindled my interest in Angular.

The tutorial evolved from .NET Core version 2.1, through 2.2 to 3.0, Neil does a fantastic job at keeping the content concise and up to date at all times.

I very highly recommend this tutorial as it's a true goldmine!

results.content: I changed my rating from a 5 to a 4.5 as I have now made it to the end of the course and noticed that the instructor is pasting in a lot of the code. He is under the impression that we would not want to see him write the code, but I believe that he is sadly mistaken. When I learn a new skill, I need to do it around 8-10 before it sticks and I can recall without notes, I would say he covers things about 3 times before starting the copying and pasting technique.  I see how this could save time, but I would rather have a 40 hour detailed course instead of a 20 hour course that cuts corners here and there. Don't get me wrong, if you are looking for a .NET Core/Angular course, you will find nothing better as of yet on Udemy, but I still think this course can be improved.

results.content: I have tried several different courses on Udemy and they all have the same old start from ingridients and build up from that until you eventually have a bread at the end. In my eyes this is very backward since you have no "hooks" for  the new information in the sense that you don't know where it fits in. This is one of the first courses I have seen here that have the, in my view, better way of deconstructing bread. That being said; this puts huge demands on the teacher to explain things in a summarized way to make you understand enough to follow the deconstruction process. In my view this is a bit lacking in this course and requires you to figure a lot about by yourself, which can be a bit frustrating. At times it feels like you are watching a programmer code at his work with little or no explanation as to why he writes what he does. All in all it's value as a deconstructor is still there and it gives you a thread to follow.

results.content: It is a very good course. Touches on plenty of topics, concepts, techniques, and tools. Both projects (web API and angular client) are very well structured. Instructor follows clean coding principles (single responsibility, separation of concerns, open/close, DRY). In my opinion it is not a beginner level course, though. More like intermediate. Some concepts proved to me to be a bit difficult to fully understand at first try, so I am going to do my own research, and perhaps get some additional learning materials on things like reactive programming or web sockets. All in all, I am very satisfied with the material. To date, it is probably the best course I took on Udemy!

results.content:
Having gone through much of the legacy, and now starting over with the updates, I can honestly say this is one of the best courses I have had taken. My background is that of 10 years in industry, mostly focused on embedded systems, and I selected this course as a way of getting my feet wet in the world of web programming.

I felt the instructor did a terrific job explaining the concepts, taking me through step-by-step of the building process, showing me the results of each change that is made. I felt the tone and pace of the course were excellent.

A word of caution to anyone coming to this course who, like me, favored use of Visual Studio and had little experience with VS Code, I recommend simply using VS Code to make the experience a little bit easier. With my first pass through the course (albeit the legacy material), I attempted to force my way using Visual Studio, leading myself to encountering lots of challenges. Just use VS Code. :)

results.content:
Truly excellent course that shows in great detail how a full stack app is built with asp.net core and angular. 

Neil is very knowledgeable, is easy to understand and is very responsive in the questions. 

This course has also been updated, both for Angular and .net core which is a big plus.

I used visual studio community edition for the server .net core part as I prefer that and vs code for the angular client side so far without issue.

Not really for beginners who have never used .net or c# and a little client side familiarity is needed before tackling this. 
Angular is complex and the syntax takes some getting used to, however it is all clearly explained making learning easier. The JWT part was especially well done, and the photo uploading section is a real gem.

The app feels real world and its great to see how all the moving parts all come together. Learned some new tricks using the development tools too. Very well constructed course. 

Strongly recommend.

Thank you, Neil for putting this together!

results.content:
The course is great, the material covers lots of different subjects both back and front sides.
Neil is great, explains everything very clearly and makes it look very easy.

The only downside is two things actually - 
1) Neil doesn't cover things like: ef, migration and how the communication between the 
    spa and the api work (what i mean is how does putting [HttpPost] above a function on the server makes the relevant http post activate that function). A high level explanation would help alot. 
2) Over the course I got few bugs that originated from misspelling or closed brackets  in the wrong place, those bugs are quite hard (for me) to detect, since everything is compiled and running. I assume those bugs happen often and would have  loved to hear thumb rules to find them quickly.

results.content: The course gives a lot of detail on Angular 5 and .NetCore. It is difficult at times and it will help if you have previous knowledge of Angular, .Net and Javascript ES6. The coverage of the HttpClientService and HttpInterceptor service in the final module were welcome, but I would have liked them earlier. Overall a great practical demo of how to use Angular with .NetCore.

results.content:
Sorry for the poor english, this is not my primary language!

So I am a .NET developer who had a little break from .NET and had to get back on track with .NET core and FE frameworks. So I have some experience coding real life applications.

This course is just BRILLIANT. Some of the time, when you follow a course, the instructors goes about doing some shady things to make things works, without explaining why they do it, or they just paste a lot of cryptic codes in the editor and hope you get along with it. This is NOT the case with this course. The instructor is doing EVERYTHING from scratch and explains the decision he takes about doing things.

What I like is that he is thorough in his explanation and in the development of the app. This is not your typical "movie selector" kind of tutorial. Lots of things happening in this course can readily be applied to real world scenarios. 

An aspect some instructors seem to overlook is the deployment section. You have an app in your hand, probably coded with a technology you've never used before and they assume you can deploy it by yourself. Well, this is not the case here. The instructor teaches you multiple ways to deploy your app.

I really enjoyed this course, but this is most likely a course for more advanced developpers. Some of the concepts explained in this course may seem to go too fast if you're an abolute begnner. Also, this is not a COMPLETE Angular course, where you'll get to know everything there is to Angular. Some of the concepts could be explained a lil deeper. As I had a lot of knowledge in .NET, I easily followed those parts, but sometimes I had to stop and ask myself why some of the Angular stuff was done this way. 

Overrall, this is an excellent course and I strongly recommend it.

results.content: Overall, I liked the course. Few topics were not covered like Lazy loading in Angular. Also in some cases you explained what the problem and how to solve but Why the problem occured that you did not explain. I think explaining the root cause of problem will help to understand the concept in a better way. And last the way you explained caching looks inappropriate to me. From What I have seen we mostly cache the response from API because over there we have greater control. Client side caching we don't have control so we can't override the cache as we want to. So, if you would have covered how to cache API response at server, it would be better. Thank you for the course.

results.content: Neil did a great job with this course. It is very in depth, covering a lot of ground and is a good introduction to both ASP.NET and Angular. The only reason I don't give this 5 stars is because I felt the course went too fast at times. I realize that the course covers a lot of ground, and it is already almost 30 hours long, but sometimes the explanations of why certain code behaves the way it does fell short for me, I just needed more explanation. Overall, I am glad I took the course and finished it, but I will definitely need to use other resources to have a better understanding of the content, especially for Angular. One really nice thing about this particular course, was that the community asks and answer a lot of question. I submitted a few questions, and even Neil answered within a few hours which really helped me maintain progress and get to the finish line. Thanks Neil, for all of your efforts. I look forward to taking more of your courses!

results.content: This course covers a lot of ground and provides an interesting example app as a jumping off point for learning Angular. Unfortunately, for better or worse the course is presented as if you're just watching a journeyman developer work though building an app. In a lot of places, the code ends up being not an especially good example of TypeScript best practices. As the presenter goes through writing the code the VS Code Intellisense is continually flashing all over the place preventing the student from following what he is discussing in many cases. (It should have been disabled for the purposes of the course.) And in a lot of cases the course bogs down discussing things that are not particularly important (like Cloudinary integration) while glossing over Angular topics that could have used deeper discussion (like perhaps nesting within reactive forms, app modularization, etc.). In all, it was an interesting course, but could have been much tighter with a little more up front organization.
results.content_html: This course covers a lot of ground and provides an interesting example app as a jumping off point for learning Angular. Unfortunately, for better or worse the course is presented as if you're just watching a journeyman developer work though building an app. In a lot of places, the code ends up being not an especially good example of TypeScript best practices. As the presenter goes through writing the code the VS Code Intellisense is continually flashing all over the place preventing the student from following what he is discussing in many cases. (It should have been disabled for the purposes of the course.) And in a lot of cases the course bogs down discussing things that are not particularly important (like Cloudinary integration) while glossing over Angular topics that could have used deeper discussion (like perhaps nesting within reactive forms, app modularization, etc.). In all, it was an interesting course, but could have been much tighter with a little more up front organization.

results.content:
Neil seems to be patient with all questions that may arise from students. I really appreciate his responsiveness and friendliness. 

Regarding the content of this course, I know it may be hard to keep its content up-to-date since technologies are always evolving too fast. I hope next versions of Angular be backward-compatible with the samples we see in this course. 

The sample site is a real world app that would prepare you to create simple sites in a short time. I really would like to see more courses from Neil, mainly regarding microservices with .NET Core, that would be really enjoyable! The only drawback are some videos that seem to be out of sync, the code already done in previous lectures got changed in future ones, and you do not know when did the teacher changed them or why your code won't compile. This is what is happening at the moment, some lectures starting at 141 are hard to follow and seem to be broken. No one among current learners have posted messages regarding the issues and this situation does make me think the lectures were correct at some point in time. Some properties in DbContext may appear in singular and then you may find them in plural: it is confusing sometimes to get along. 

Also, I would say you need to have an intermediate or high level skill in C# with LINQ and some basic Angular knowledge in order to follow up this course. You also must be a curious person in order to try to get over the issues from UI third party components such as ngx boostrap. 

Calendar can be a headache, so read the questions and answers to overcome those problems. Right now the biggest problem with this course besides the UI third party components are the SQL Lite database, which at this moment does not allow you to drop foreign keys, so you have to remove all your migrations yourself and recreate them using your newest model. There is no video teaching you that, so some research is necessary. 

The latest issue I had was with CreateAsync for RoleManager and UserManager within Seed class using SQL Server, which I had overcome. Again, for this issue with CreateAsync, read the Q&A to help you out. 

The worst part of this course in my opinion is migrating all you have done from Angular 5 to Angular 6 because this causes some breaking changes. It can take days to make your app work again if you start modifying files individually. :'-( 

In general, I do recommend this course for senior developers but not for beginners. 

My overall impression is good. Neil did a nice work!
results.content_html:

Regarding the content of this course, I know it may be hard to keep its content up-to-date since technologies are always evolving too fast. I hope next versions of Angular be backward-compatible with the samples we see in this course.

The sample site is a real world app that would prepare you to create simple sites in a short time. I really would like to see more courses from Neil, mainly regarding microservices with .NET Core, that would be really enjoyable! The only drawback are some videos that seem to be out of sync, the code already done in previous lectures got changed in future ones, and you do not know when did the teacher changed them or why your code won't compile. This is what is happening at the moment, some lectures starting at 141 are hard to follow and seem to be broken. No one among current learners have posted messages regarding the issues and this situation does make me think the lectures were correct at some point in time. Some properties in DbContext may appear in singular and then you may find them in plural: it is confusing sometimes to get along.

Also, I would say you need to have an intermediate or high level skill in C# with LINQ and some basic Angular knowledge in order to follow up this course. You also must be a curious person in order to try to get over the issues from UI third party components such as ngx boostrap.

Calendar can be a headache, so read the questions and answers to overcome those problems. Right now the biggest problem with this course besides the UI third party components are the SQL Lite database, which at this moment does not allow you to drop foreign keys, so you have to remove all your migrations yourself and recreate them using your newest model. There is no video teaching you that, so some research is necessary.

The latest issue I had was with CreateAsync for RoleManager and UserManager within Seed class using SQL Server, which I had overcome. Again, for this issue with CreateAsync, read the Q&A to help you out.

The worst part of this course in my opinion is migrating all you have done from Angular 5 to Angular 6 because this causes some breaking changes. It can take days to make your app work again if you start modifying files individually. :'-(

In general, I do recommend this course for senior developers but not for beginners.

My overall impression is good. Neil did a nice work!

results.content:
I would like to thank Neil for a brilliant and well detailed course.
This helped out a lot especially in explaining the communication between angular and dotnet as well as the basics. I would probably have to review this course again but it was helpful non the less.

My only issue was a lot of things kept getting chopped and changed and it made the course a little confusing at times. I would suggest structuring the course into mini projects. that way people could get used to all the routine procedures, cli commands, database creation, database re-installation all the basic stuff. it is more difficult going back to previous lectures to repeat last procedures when its much clearer to see how everything works on different projects.

For deployment if you decide to add a section on how to deploy to more widely used webhosts, especially those that make use of cpanel and phpmyadmin i would definitely gift this course. that is the last missing piece as i dont think i will be using digital oceans premade servers. some of us have our own servers and would like to learn how to upload to there manually from scratch. I have a complete program but don't know how to upload it where I want to upload it.

Other than that the instructor is always spot on and is quick to help you solve any problem. the course is easy to follow from start to end. I would definitely buy more related courses off you in future. He is very helpful, patient and knowledgeable.  Thanks again Neil :)

When it comes to the Angular side of things, I feel very little is actually explained & what is explained goes completely over my head. As such I'm going to have to request a refund & try something different before coming back to this in the future.

I was fine originally with using VSCode but there are so many downloads for this - it would make a lot more sense to have covered this course in an IDE.

results.content:
The course structure is well laid out and follows a logical flow.
The course could benefit from a deeper dive into some topics as it most time feels like a "type-what-is-on-the-screen" simulator.
The instructor could add "asides" before the introduction of a new topic to dive into the framework feature.
If that cannot be done, he can provide a list of resources the student can use to get a deeper understanding.
And finally, the instructor spends too much time on language specifics that (eg what is a generic, what is an extension method, etc). These can be replaced with simple links to the documentation, and would cut down on the total course time.

results.content:
This is a review from the end of section 2—yes, this means I have only started the course and created the walking skeleton.  I realize the approach of this course is to power-through and get the walking skeleton built.  However, this comes at great cost, namely the glossing over of several essential subjects.  The target audience for this course is advertised to be a range which includes beginners.  And while you can follow along and not ask too many questions, and build something meaningful, and still gain experience— this approach IMHO is very misleading.  I will explain…
I am an experienced .NET Framework developer, but entirely new to .NET Core and using C# for Web API/App programming.  I had signed up for this course in the Fall of 2020 after having taken a bootcamp on HTML, CSS, Bootstrap and JavaScript. I mention this so perhaps you can gauge yourself accordingly.
By the time we reached the Entity Framework portion of the walking-skeleton, I had so many questions and so much I did not understand, so I ejected.  For example, I did not understand all the aspects of the IHostBuilder and the significance of it.  Or about Dependency Injection, Entity Framework or Data Access in general.  It also seemed wrong (and it completely is) to build your Data Access (Entity Framework) right into your API project!  This should be separated into a Class Library.  Maybe just my opinion, but I feel very strongly about that.
Anyway, I ejected from the course in the Fall of 2020, and returned in the Spring of 2021, after having taken ~8 months of other courses.  I learned all about all the ASP.NET Core Web project types—API, MVC, Razor, Blazor Server, and Blazor Client.  I learned about Dependency Injection, employment of C# Class Library projects, implementing Data Access to SQL and NoSQL databases, both with and without Entity Framework—especially some huge pitfalls of EF with Microsoft SQL to watch out for.
Thus, I am back!  It is Spring of 2021 and now I am better equipped to take this course.  The moral here is student beware!  I am not saying this is a bad course—it looks like a great course, however the approach to dive right in without building the necessary core/foundational concepts will come back to bite you in the real world.  Do not build your database (and data access) within your API project—use a Class Library—they are free, as many as you want!  So just beware and do not be afraid to search for other courses or videos on the subjects you do not fully understand.

results.content: The author says this course is beginner friendly. I disagree. You need an advanced level of understanding of C# to understand what is going on in the code because the author doesn't do very much explaining as to what the code is doing. Often times I found myself writing code and not having a single idea what it's doing. Lecture 41 is a good example of this. We're writing endless amounts of code, but the author is just telling us what to write rather than sufficiently explaining how all of it ties together or works.

results.content:
Though I have just started the course, by looking at the content and the demo application, course seems really comprehensive and well structured. The thing that I especially liked was JWT token authentication and a use of non-microsoft database. I have worked in 3 companies till now that used ASP.NET or .NET Core and all used non-MS dbs. None of them used Azure or ASP Identity authentication, but when it comes to finding resources online all are complete MS solutions. This course I think shines in that way it uses SQLite in Dev and MySQL in PROD. I am definitely gonna update my review as I progress further.

UPDATE1 - Completed Authentication Section: Things got better in this module. I have never seen such a clear explanation of JWT authentication ever. Also the explanation of Repository pattern which forms the core the DB layer in ASP.NET application is on point.

results.content: I definitely recommend this course.  The course takes the approach of building one web application and enhancing it throughout the course, and I think that is a good approach.  Not only do you learn about Angular and .Net Core web APIs, but you learn how to make them co-exist in one solution and work with both in VS Code, which is a topic I have not seen elsewhere.  In addition, you will learn about EF Core, work with a cloud image-storage service called Cloudinary, and utilize Bootstrap CSS classes and the ngx-bootstrap library to make a nice-looking site.  The course also covers building and publishing your solutions to production, which is also seldom covered.  The instructor has updated the course several times to keep it up-to-date and is active answering questions in the Q&A section for the course.
results.content_html: I definitely recommend this course. The course takes the approach of building one web application and enhancing it throughout the course, and I think that is a good approach. Not only do you learn about Angular and .Net Core web APIs, but you learn how to make them co-exist in one solution and work with both in VS Code, which is a topic I have not seen elsewhere. In addition, you will learn about EF Core, work with a cloud image-storage service called Cloudinary, and utilize Bootstrap CSS classes and the ngx-bootstrap library to make a nice-looking site. The course also covers building and publishing your solutions to production, which is also seldom covered. The instructor has updated the course several times to keep it up-to-date and is active answering questions in the Q&A section for the course.

results.content:
Must have course for any .Net developer. The course is very well structured. Neil updates the course all the time, and he helped me in the comments when I needed it. At the end you will have a well organised app architecture ready to scale in both back and front end.

Now that I have completed 100% of the course, I will look into changing the design of the client to use vanilla CSS (Grid/Flexbox) instead of Bootstrap and give it my personal touch. I would also like to add some functionality, like the possibility for users to delete their accounts and a few more things. Best thing is, I feel like I can do those things after doing this course.

results.content: This is a course of high quality. The course is well structured. The content is current (ASP.NET Core 2 and Angular). One downside of this course is that although the instructor explains every bit of the content reasonably clear and in detail, the explanations does not go deep. Sometimes, if a programmer really wants to advance his/her skills to another level, the details under the hook are very important too. I sincerely wish the instructor could create another course on the topic, but goes deeper, like explaining more about the OWIN pipeline and Kestrel server, and how their relationships between IIS and ASP.NET Core Web API. Nevertheless, I give this course a 5-start rating.

Thanks!

results.content: The course is well structured and organized. Sometimes, especially towards the end, it seems the trainer goes faster through the content. Also, there has been some gaps between his code and mine. I am not sure if I missed something or maybe the re-upload of the new version of this course left something accidentally out. Sure, it’s not a design pattern course but maybe the focus or the detail of the used pattern could have been more explained. In my opinion there should have been a little bit more separation of concerns. Maybe some real-world scenarios of how this pattern is used or not. I am missing some clean code approaches too, for example some good comments. All in all, it’s a good starter tutorial. Thanks for the good time.

results.content:
Neil is fantastic. I am educated and experienced and yet I was able to learn from him much more than I expected. This is the course that I originally bought last year because I needed to refresh my .NET (switching back from java). As soon as I realized what a gem he truly is, I bought the other three courses (with React, Firestore, more Angular/.NET and other stuff). 
All beautiful, all great, all very useful. All pleasure to follow, both for Neil’s development style and brit accent.
He even goes so far that he re-records a complete course every year or two just to keep it relevant and up-to-date… 
I highly recommend all of them.

I found Neil's course to be exceptionally well created with a lot of knowledge just waiting to be absorbed. I normally do not comment on accent/voice but I found Neil to have a positive tone and that really helps learners in my opinion. Its truly a shame he hasn't got more courses at the moment but I will be willing to purchase further courses based on my current experience. Additionally, Neil has been active in the Q & A section which is really great. I am happy to endorse Neil as an amazing instructor and wholeheartedly recommend purchasing this course for anyone looking to learn dotnet core with Angular.

Overall a great presentation

results.content:
The instructor says what he is doing (which I can see on the screen), but not why he is doing it, nor does he explain the underlying concepts. For example: he tells you to add a certain line of code to the app.module file, but he doesn't explain what that file does or what the different sections are. So at the end I still don't know what I'm doing.

The course is really a type along. But at the parts where you have to type extensive pieces of code the instructor goes way to fast. That is annoying.

I feel that and the end of the course the application works, but I wouldn't want to build on it for a larger application. I don't feel this is scalable.

results.content: From development to production, a very complete course. When I started this course, I took an additional challenge of building the application using Angular 6, .Net Core 2.0 and Bootstrap 4 from the start. Neil is engaging and follows a very well defined and detailed path, explaining what you are going to do and how, along the way. I took my time, trying to fix things on my own, taking the pace, and watched Neil build the parts and fit the pieces together at the same time. It was a wonderful experience. I learned a lot about .Net Core and Angular 6. I had some previous experience in MVC and Entity Framework, but even without that prior experience this course is very accessible. Thank you Neil!

results.content:
The course is brilliant!
It is one of the most well spent money given the amount of information that is presented.
The author have deep knowledge of both technologies - dotnet core and angular and that makes the course great.
Also the author handles every bug/issue that arises and don't leave it behind.
He is very responsive to the Q&A section and i was able to find solutions for my problems from there a couple of times.

I highly recommend this course for guys like me that already have decent .net knowledge and want to combine their existing knowledge with angular.

The end result of the course is a perfect boilerplate for future projects.

It covers most of the common tasks that you want to handle when you are developing a web application such as: Master/Detail view, filtering, pagination, file upload, messaging system and more.

If you are wandering whether you should get the course or not - do it - it is worth it!

Best Regards,
Dido

results.content:
This course was honestly great, gives you more than enough foundation to then progress in depth into most features, plus the actual project was worth doing. There are some points that make you question whether this would be the technique you would use but even the instructor alludes to this allowing him to showcase more techniques.
But boy, every time he says "boo-le-an" it makes one of your eyes uncontrollably spasm.

results.content:
First of all, wow. I got this course with the intention of brushing up on .NET Core, but little did I know that I was going to learn new Angular skills through Neil's examples that finally turned on the light bulb for me in subjects that I didn't fully understand before (ie; RxJS).

I would say that the pace of this course makes the entry level for it somewhere between beginner and intermediate. It's less focused on the very basics of .NET Core and Angular, such as what Object Oriented Programming or basic high level knowledge of programming itself. Rather, the course focuses on real world implementations and strategies that are actually useful to understand. For example, the error handling section is amazing, and I wish more instructors covered something that is so fundamental in production apps as well as Neil does in his course.

I did the challenge at the end and my solution was very similar to Neil's, which I am taking as a sign that he has taught me well! I did a few things differently, some I liked my way better and some I liked his, so it was nice to stretch out but still be learning at the end!
The challenges were great and I think more would have keep people engaged, as it is a lot of time listening/reading/typing.. but I did this in a pretty condensed fashion so that would make the feeling exacerbated
Thanks!

results.content: If you're trying to get started with .Net Core, this course is a great way to get your feet wet with it; however, many of the .Net Core concepts are not explained in detail. Most of the time, the instructor tells you what to do, but not why or how it works. Also, the Angular side doesn't follow best practices laid out by the style guide in the Angular docs. I recognize there are different ways of doing things, but in this case it means that his Angular app isn't scalable. His file structure would make it extremely difficult to implement multiple modules and techniques like lazy loading modules to improve performance.

results.content:
A good and comprehensive course. It covers many of the aspects of building an app from start to finish. I think it's excellent for people who, like myself, have learned how to code and are ready to take the next step and start building full-scale applications using some coding frameworks and libraries, in this case ASP.NET Core and Angular. I also in particular liked the section about publishing an app because it was entirely new ground for me as well.

On occasion I thought the coding went rather fast and it was a bit hard to follow right away without pausing and rewinding, and sometimes there are a lot of built in methods and classes used from the frameworks that are not always fully explained. I did not find this too big a deal because I'm okay looking up the documentation  as well, but I could imagine some people might like some more thorough explanations  for some parts. That being said, a great course overall, definitely a good choice for relatively new programmers who want to start building full-scale applications.
results.content_html:
A good and comprehensive course. It covers many of the aspects of building an app from start to finish. I think it's excellent for people who, like myself, have learned how to code and are ready to take the next step and start building full-scale applications using some coding frameworks and libraries, in this case ASP.NET Core and Angular. I also in particular liked the section about publishing an app because it was entirely new ground for me as well.

On occasion I thought the coding went rather fast and it was a bit hard to follow right away without pausing and rewinding, and sometimes there are a lot of built in methods and classes used from the frameworks that are not always fully explained. I did not find this too big a deal because I'm okay looking up the documentation as well, but I could imagine some people might like some more thorough explanations for some parts. That being said, a great course overall, definitely a good choice for relatively new programmers who want to start building full-scale applications.

results.content: I take exception to the idea that this course is for beginners. Yes, if you follow the instruction, you should be able to complete this course but a beginner is going to be seriously challenged trying to understand all of the concepts which are often rattled off at break-neck speed. The Walking Skeleton lecture early on was probably the most useful part of understanding how all of this works together. By the end of the program I do have a functional application but my ability to talk about it is somewhat limited. Some quizzes focused on key concepts along the way would be very helpful in getting a person to talk about angular and .net intelligently (such as for an interview).

Der Kurs bietet einen hervorragenden Überblick über die Entwicklung einer SPA mit .NET Core und Angular. Neil Cummings vermittelten den kompletten Workflow der Anwendungsentwicklung von der Auswahl aller benötigten Tools und Ressourcen bis zum Deployment der App im Internet. Deutsche Untertitel sind vorhanden, werden aber meines Erachtens nicht benötigt. Alle Themen werden in einem sehr angenehmen Tempo vermittelt.

Thank you Neil - an excellent job!!

results.content: The course was excellent. This is definitely not a beginner's course and I don't believe Neil advertised it as such. I highly recommend taking a course in basic C# and JavaScript knowledge before doing a course like this. I had about 2 years experience in C# and JavaScript so I was able to follow it well, but I also can see that a course like this may cause those completely new to C#/JS to struggle a bit (or even a lot). Nevertheless, I enjoyed Neil's adherence to certain coding practices, such as the use of interface to decouple classes, and he's probably the first C# instructor I've seen on Udemy who correctly uses pascal casing for C# class properties. Of course, there are also times he broke coding practices (such as not making proper use of TypeScript), but that was because he wanted to explain things without adding complexity to the code, which is fine as he fixes those conventions later on when he dove into more advance subjects. There's A LOT to take in for this course, and I will likely have to rewatch this course a few times, but I enjoy that there was so much to learn.

results.content: Neil has a brilliant way of teaching! I'm glad i purchased this course. I have some experience in software development and can tell this course is very well structured. Neil explains in an engaging manner, no bells and whistles just good old knowledge transfer and shows the development of an entire project from scratch to deployment to Heroku. Surprisingly, within a few starting lectures, i felt confident that his teaching style will help me learn this topic very well. And I'm excited at the possibility of being able to finally build that project I've been wanting to for a long time. Thanks a ton Neil for putting up this course. This is a 5 stars course for me! I'd heartily recommend this course to anyone looking to learn to build with .Net + Angular tech stack.

results.content:
Fantastic end to end example of building the web application using ASP NET Core & Angular.

results.content: I'm not completely through this course yet, so this review is based on my current progress. I'm 70% through the course in 2 days (very committed to learning and breaking through logical barriers, thanks to an engaging and helpful instructor) and initially I started out by trying to mirror every line of code from the instructor which left me with a lot of errors (mostly typos or similar) and a lack of understanding of how to debug those. So I started over and this time watched an entire module at a time and then started recreating the course  with a real-world example of my own. This really helped me get the grasp of what I was doing and with the possibility to go back and forth in the module and listen to Neil was a nice reference along with research on the web. I know C# and other languages quiet well but web development requires getting the grasp of multiple tools and synergies between those, thanks to Neil I see everything more clear for every module I complete.

results.content: I like how Neil slowly explains things, it allows for understanding the internal workings a lot better! I keep forgetting that this course is for creating an angular app, and not teaching how Angular works. I am new to angular, so a lot of things mentioned, I don't always know what certain things are or how it works, so I am assuming this course is for people who already have a little experience and knowledge of the fundamentals. However, with this being said, this is helping me to know how things plug in together, from API to the Angular app and then making changes to the front end.

results.content:
One of the best Author on Udemy! And not only on Udemy :)
He updates all (ALL) his Courses with new Versions of used Technologies!

Not only this. He also add additional Features/Topics! 
Simply take a look to a total length of Courses. It's more than 30 Hours of Content. And Neil doesn't combine the parts of existing Courses with new one. So with every new Product you become more or less 30 Hours of new Information!

All the Courses have a practical advices how to solve some Problems. If you are looking for something with mostly theoretical explanation, that it's not for you.

But if you want to see how to use Angular and .NET - take this one!
